subject: Re: [junit] How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... Have you really never tried to work your way through a mess of JavaDoc with no easy way to figure out what classes you needed and what you could ignore?
messageBody:
Ilja Preuss wrote:

> I don't think that's true. I don't see how having an additional
> org.something.util.CalendarParser class could make any library harder to
> understand and use. Hell, that class could even be extracted to a different
> binary, so that an outside developer wouldn't see it at all.

Have you really never tried to work your way through a mess of JavaDoc
with no easy way to figure out what classes you needed and what you
could ignore? Has it been that long since you learned a new API?
Featuritis isn't just a problem for applications. It applies to
libraries too. Smaller is better. Too large an API becomes a problem.

Trying to bring this back on topic, the JUnit 3.8 API is a good example.
It's actually pretty small but not as small as it could or should be.
Take a look at http://www.junit.org/junit/javadoc/3.8.1/index.htm How
much of that does a programmer actually need to know? How easy is it for
someone trying to learn the API to figure what they need to do and where
to get started? Even experienced users can have trouble finding a
relatively unfamiliar class, and that's a small API as APIs go, and much
better documented than most. Probably half of what's there could be
non-public, and users would be the better off for it if it were. What
benefit is served by making junit.samples or TestResult$1 public?
